HULLABALOO BILLS
MUST BE PAID
Bills for pictures sent out by
the Hullabaloo to various activities and fraternities must be
paid by April 1st. The year is
rapidly progressing and all
matters must be attended to as
soon as possible. If the bills
are not paid before April 1st
the pictures of the various activities and fraternities will not
appear in the year book.
Special attention is also urged
to be given to all other notices
sent out by the Hullabaloo.

STAGE WALKER CHEERS UP COLD
AUDIENCE OF "IF I WERE KING"

HULLABALOO METHOD
OF ELECTJON CHANGED
George Gump, chairman of
the Board of Editors of the
Hullabaloo, was empowered
by the Junior Class at a meeting held yesterday in the C. E.
Hall to draw up a constitution
for the Hullabaloo. It was
stipulated that the election of
the officers of the year book
be taken out of the hands of
the Junior Class as a whole,
and that it should be given
over to the board of control of
the Hullabaloo. This action
was taken because many objections arose to the old system of the election of the Editor-in-Chief and the Business
Manager of the year book by
a body which did not know
the respective merits of the
candidates.

TRACK SQUAD IS
I MAKING HEADWAY

A Stray College Boy, the hero of
many He and She jokes, walked
across the stage during the crucial
scene in the second act of- "If I
Were King" last night and made a
skeptical audience forget that they
were freezing.; that numerous seats
were collecting dust for want, of
cash customers; and that the first
act might have been portrayed with
a greater skill.
Not that the Stray College Boy
was associated in any way with the
dramatic business of the evening.
Far from it. What stimulated the
humors of last night's Barnstormer
patrons was the presentation of the
walking speciman of the naive, unadulterated College Boy—the College Boy of the joke books who
walks through life influenced only
by simple instincts and puerile
co-eds.
At all events, matters were not
running at their smoothest when
the Barnstormers finally managed
to lift the curtain on their initial
act. Perhaps the audience required
an interlude to grasp the idea that
the play was not essentially a humorous one and that it didn't matter that the curves of male-female
actors aren't the most convincing.
But the atmosphere ultimately
brightened in the second act and
from then on the Barnstormers rendered more interestingly a portrayal of what might have been historic France.

EDITORIALS

lazily smothers a yawn and says, "Well, we might as well saunter over
to the field and watch the team beat up Yale."
We have some cheer leaders at Hopkins and they (poor devils)
work hard, but get very disappointing results. The reason is that those
undergraduates who deign to sit in the rooting section feel no responsibility toward doing their little bit to help the team along. They go
to a lacrosse game in the same spirit that they go to a movie; for an
afternoon's enjoyment and nothing more. There has been a lot of
criticism in the past few years against the college rah-rah spirit. Hop, kins has taken it seriously, much too seriously. The rah-rah spirit when
it serves as an outlet for a superabundance of youthful animal spirits
is a fine and useful manifestation. When it exceeds natural inclinations (as at the Annihilation of Annapolis, for instance) it becomes
absurd. But we at Hopkins have become too prone to go to the other
extreme and suppress a great deal of natural exhilaration at athletic
.contests. This extreme is worse than the other, as we believe the
psychologists will agree.
Once we get rid of the idea that a wonderful lacrosse team is to be
,expected and a merely good one to be deplored and rid ourselves of
the delusion that it is always bad taste to make a noise, the team will
get the support it deserves.

long been our contention that the honorary society has been clinging
to an out-worn tradition in holding their elections so late in the year.

elect at a reasonable date this year, but we congratulate the society on
the step just the same.

body requesting the renewal of football relations with Haverford in
1931. In order to determine the sentiment of alumni and friends of the
college on this question, a questionnaire has been presented; the
same means have been adopted at
the 'University of Haverford. The
history of the Haverford-Swarthmore football question is extremely
interesting: the first game was held
in 1879, but due to the unpopularity
of the sport, no contest was again
held until 1884. From then until
1904, with the exception of 1896
when the game was cancelled because o fthe death of a Swarthmore
player the football contest was an
annual event. A change in Swarthmore's policy of "good feeling and
kind treatment," according to the
Haverford News, resulted in a severance of relations. An attempt was
made to heal the break, resulting in
the establishment of the Haverford
News as a means of resuming relations. The result was favorable, and
the contest continued to be an annual event until 1925 when relations
were again severed because Haverford authorities declared that "It
is unwise to close the season with a
college whose widely differing athletic policies produce a condition of
inequality in football competition.

HULLABALOO BILLS
MUST BE PAID
Bills for pictures sent out by
the Hullabaloo to various activities and fraternities must be
paid by April 1st. The year is
rapidly progressing and all
matters must be attended to as
soon as possible. If the bills
are not paid before April 1st
the pictures of the various activities and fraternities will not
appear in the year book.
Special attention is also urged
to be given to all other notices
sent out by the Hullabaloo.

AUDIENCE OF "IF I WERE KING"

HULLABALOO METHOD
OF ELECTJON CHANGED
George Gump, chairman of
the Board of Editors of the
Hullabaloo, was empowered
by the Junior Class at a meeting held yesterday in the C. E.
Hall to draw up a constitution
for the Hullabaloo. It was
stipulated that the election of
the officers of the year book
be taken out of the hands of
the Junior Class as a whole,
and that it should be given
over to the board of control of
the Hullabaloo. This action
was taken because many objections arose to the old system of the election of the Editor-in-Chief and the Business
Manager of the year book by
a body which did not know
the respective merits of the
candidates.

TRACK SQUAD IS
I MAKING HEADWAY

A Stray College Boy, the hero of
many He and She jokes, walked
across the stage during the crucial
scene in the second act of- "If I
Were King" last night and made a
skeptical audience forget that they
were freezing.; that numerous seats
were collecting dust for want, of
cash customers; and that the first
act might have been portrayed with
a greater skill.
Not that the Stray College Boy
was associated in any way with the
dramatic business of the evening.
Far from it. What stimulated the
humors of last night's Barnstormer
patrons was the presentation of the
walking speciman of the naive, unadulterated College Boy—the College Boy of the joke books who
walks through life influenced only
by simple instincts and puerile
co-eds.
At all events, matters were not
running at their smoothest when
the Barnstormers finally managed
to lift the curtain on their initial
act. Perhaps the audience required
an interlude to grasp the idea that
the play was not essentially a humorous one and that it didn't matter that the curves of male-female
actors aren't the most convincing.
But the atmosphere ultimately
brightened in the second act and
from then on the Barnstormers rendered more interestingly a portrayal of what might have been historic France.

EDITORIALS

lazily smothers a yawn and says, "Well, we might as well saunter over
to the field and watch the team beat up Yale."
We have some cheer leaders at Hopkins and they (poor devils)
work hard, but get very disappointing results. The reason is that those
undergraduates who deign to sit in the rooting section feel no responsibility toward doing their little bit to help the team along. They go
to a lacrosse game in the same spirit that they go to a movie; for an
afternoon's enjoyment and nothing more. There has been a lot of
criticism in the past few years against the college rah-rah spirit. Hop, kins has taken it seriously, much too seriously. The rah-rah spirit when
it serves as an outlet for a superabundance of youthful animal spirits
is a fine and useful manifestation. When it exceeds natural inclinations (as at the Annihilation of Annapolis, for instance) it becomes
absurd. But we at Hopkins have become too prone to go to the other
extreme and suppress a great deal of natural exhilaration at athletic
.contests. This extreme is worse than the other, as we believe the
psychologists will agree.
Once we get rid of the idea that a wonderful lacrosse team is to be
,expected and a merely good one to be deplored and rid ourselves of
the delusion that it is always bad taste to make a noise, the team will
get the support it deserves.

body requesting the renewal of football relations with Haverford in
1931. In order to determine the sentiment of alumni and friends of the
college on this question, a questionnaire has been presented; the
same means have been adopted at
the 'University of Haverford. The
history of the Haverford-Swarthmore football question is extremely
interesting: the first game was held
in 1879, but due to the unpopularity
of the sport, no contest was again
held until 1884. From then until
1904, with the exception of 1896
when the game was cancelled because o fthe death of a Swarthmore
player the football contest was an
annual event. A change in Swarthmore's policy of "good feeling and
kind treatment," according to the
Haverford News, resulted in a severance of relations. An attempt was
made to heal the break, resulting in
the establishment of the Haverford
News as a means of resuming relations. The result was favorable, and
the contest continued to be an annual event until 1925 when relations
were again severed because Haverford authorities declared that "It
is unwise to close the season with a
college whose widely differing athletic policies produce a condition of
inequality in football competition.
